title: Summer books of 2021: History
text:
The Gun, the Ship and the Pen: Warfare, Constitutions and the Making of the Modern World
by Linda Colley, Profile Books £25/$35

Colley ranges from the US, western Europe and Russia to Haiti, Japan and Tahiti in charting how constitutions became a defining characteristic of modernity in the 18th and 19th centuries. She has written a global history of remarkable depth, imagination and insight.

The Horde: How the Mongols Changed the World
by Marie Favereau, The Belknap Press £23.95/$29.95

In medieval European times, the Mongols ruled a vast area of the Eurasian landmass stretching as far to the west as modern Ukraine. Favereau, a French specialist on nomadic empires, achieves the exceptional feat of writing about this era in a way that is accessible to general readers as well as scholarly.

The Volga: A History of Russia's Greatest River
by Janet M Hartley, Yale University Press £25

Hartley's study of the Volga, the river that symbolises Russian identity, is a worthy companion to her 2014 book Siberia: A History of the People. She is particularly good on the way that Russians and non-Russians interacted in the centuries after Ivan the Terrible's conquest of Kazan and Astrakhan in the 1550s.

The Spectre of War: International Communism and the Origins of World War II
by Jonathan Haslam, Princeton University Press £30/$35

Anyone interested in global tensions in the interwar period will learn much from the latest book by Haslam, a Princeton University historian. He draws on a lifetime of expertise on the Soviet Union and Russian foreign policy to explain how fear of communism permeated international relations after 1917.

The Movement: The African American Struggle for Civil Rights
by Thomas C Holt, Oxford University Press £14.99

The Republican party's efforts at voter suppression since the 2020 US presidential election give a special resonance to Holt's book on the civil rights movement of the mid 20th century. It is a concise, lucid and well-balanced account by one of America's best historians of the topic.

Blood and Iron: The Rise and Fall of the German Empire 1871-1918
by Katja Hoyer, The History Press £14.99

The themes of political fragility, social cleavages and pervasive militarism give a convincing coherence to Hoyer's tightly written narrative of German history between 1871 and 1918. She is rightly sceptical of the once fashionable idea that Germany was on a “special path” that distinguished its development from that of Britain, France or the US.

The Anglo-Saxons: A History of the Beginnings of England
by Marc Morris, Hutchinson £25

The foundations of the English state and identity were laid in the seven centuries between the end of Roman rule in Britain and the Norman Conquest of 1066. Morris avoids the mythmaking that once marred histories of this period and composes a lively narrative that is perceptive and well-researched.

The Scent of Empires: Chanel No 5 and Red Moscow
by Karl Schlögel, translated by Jessica Spengler, Polity £20

Fragrant perfumes are not odours one normally associates with the defunct Soviet Union. Schlögel, a German historian best known for Moscow 1937, a brilliant study of life under Joseph Stalin's Great Terror, has broken unusual ground by writing a comparative history of Soviet and French perfume-making.

Napoleon: A Life in Gardens and Shadows
by Ruth Scurr, Chatto & Windus £30

Exactly 200 years after his death, it might seem an impossible challenge to write something new about Napoleon Bonaparte, but Scurr has managed it. The Cambridge historian examines the French emperor's interest in the natural world in a book that is stimulating and highly original.

The Partition: Ireland Divided, 1885-1925
by Charles Townshend, Allen Lane £25

The Brexit referendum campaign of 2016 and subsequent controversies over Northern Ireland's status illustrate how political struggles on the British mainland risk dividing and destabilising the province. Townshend, a leading scholar of modern Irish history, has written an authoritative study of the origins of Ireland's partition.
